text: - Hi, I'm Ron Wedel.

I'm a senior partner solutions
architect here at AWS.
- Hi, I'm Rahul Kochhar,

also senior Solution
architect here at AWS.
- Rahul, when we talk about
modern application architectures,

the word container comes
up very frequently.
Can you tell me some of the benefits
of why customers are leveraging containers
or wanna migrate to containers today?
- Sure, Ron.

Containers are definitely the
way companies, enterprises,
and startups are now building application.

It provides the lowest common
denominator of portability,

that you can run the workload
across any environment.

So portability is one of
the important feature,

and the fact that each
container represents,

and containers can represent
a set of microservices.
So it is definitely on the rise
towards building the modern application,
where developers have autonomy

of building their own
microservices on top of containers.
And so developer productivity goes up.

The fact that container is
not a full virtual machine,
the fact it's only subset of the code

and the important dependencies
that makes that application
that much more smaller in form factor
saves a lot of IT infrastructure.

And the fact that you could
do it at scale deployment

day in and out, and they
can scale up and down
means that the infrastructure

can really sustain the
demands of the application

and the developer productivity
that we are looking at.

- So, I mean, it sounds
like a great idea to be able

to simplify the developer
software lifecycle

and also drive down
costs and increase scale

and shorten time to
market for our customers.
- All done through standard CICD process,

which is how the teams
and the organizations
are looking to do a software supply chain.
- So that sounds great for customers today
building new green field applications.
Let's talk about, say a customer

who has an old Windows
server, say Windows 2008,

on premises, or even in
physical form factor,

or perhaps has some older
Linux virtual machines running
and they have some legacy apps, say IIS,
or .NET for their windows.
- Sure.
- Or even some Java applications
running on their Linux virtual machines.

How are they gonna start to
be able to take advantage
of that modern container architecture,

without necessarily having the
resources on premises today
that understand that old legacy code base?
- Sure.
So Ron, this is where App2Container
can really be the tool of the choice

to help customers in their
modernization journey.

The way it happens is we
first deploy a small agent
of App2C on every server that you want
that's running an application

where you want to start that
application transformation.
That application, that agent,

connects to the AWS
account of the customer,
and you would set it up to configure
exactly like how you would do the CDK,
which means you provide it a role,

you provide it the
connectivity, the account IDs,

and the region where you
want that virtual machine

and the application running
in the virtual machine
to be containerized to.

So you define the source
and then the destination.

So imagine in this
instance we got the source,
which is that on-prem virtual machine,

which, by the way, could
be an operating system
that is in AWS, too.
So it's not on-prem.
It could be a very good fuel
to that two step migration.
- Okay.

- Yeah, where the customers
brought the VM as an EC2,

now they wanna do the
second step to modernize.

- Excellent, so they
can continue to simplify

even if this is a supported
modern operating system,
but perhaps an IIS or .NET application
that they want to containerize.
- Yep.
- So the agent's on the source.

What's it gonna do to the source
to interrogate that source
and really build the container?

- Sure, so now that you
have installed the agent

and initialize the agent
to establish connectivity,
it's actually then gonna build

what we call as an inventory
of the application.
So for example, in this instance,

it's gonna start understanding,
it's a Windows server,

it's got IIS, it's got .NET,
it's then gonna start building

what we call as like a
analysis of the application.
So it's gonna understand, start reading

the metadata of the application,
it's gonna bring together

the dependencies of all
the different modules
that you're using,

and then it's then gonna
generate a Docker file.

At that point, you could
now change the behavior
of the application.

A very good example is, say you
want to change the TCP port,
which was running 80, to 443.
- Excellent.

- Or you were running multiple
different functionalities

and now you want to split
them as separate containers,
right, in the future state.

So this is where, once it
does the initialization,

it'll create the artifact,
it'll create the docker file,
and then you can make those changes,
as I mentioned, like TCP or a heap size.

So it'll take that
Docker file, which again,

that can be modified by the
teams and the developers.

And then once you
approve that Docker file,
it'll then do what is called as a build,

and it'll use our CICD
tools to push that code

as a Docker file into
a code deploy pipeline,
which will then deploy it either on EKS,
in this instance in EKS,

but it could be EKS, ECS,
Fargate, or App Runner.

- And this docker image
file that was created

during this process, it can
be stored in a registry,
just like any traditional Docker file

or container that's
been created in modern.

- It's then gonna understand,
okay, I have this.

So then, in an instance of
Windows, it'll understand,
oh, I need a base operating system,

which is gonna be the
base container image,
that will be the runtime.

It'll also identify, I need a
few additional dependencies.
And then it'll also add the code,
what will be the application code.
One thing I also wanna mention is,
running App2Container does not need access
to any of the underlying code,

which means, you have an
application which is running,

it'll take a snapshot of
the running application
and bring it over.

So if the customers are
running those legacy apps,

those commercial, off the
shelf software on top of IIS,
they can come in as is.

They don't need access
to the proprietary code
that made that application up.

- That sounds extremely
beneficial to customers,

like I said earlier, that
have maybe older applications

where they no longer have
access to the source code,
but need to maintain the functionality

for any number of business
or technical reasons.
One question I had is,

if you have a server,
like say in this Windows,
that has IIS and .NET,

but those are actually operating
as separate applications,

will the App2Container actually
make this a container one

and container two and go
up and into the cloud?
- It can do that.

This is where the Docker
file and the manifest

that it generates can be
tweaked, modernized, updated
for the future state deployment.
So what you could do is you could create,
if those were separate,

in fact, if there were
multiple applications
that were running across multiple servers,
they could be part of one container,

or one server, which was
running multiple applications.

For example, a lot of
customers ran multiple websites
on top of one IIS server,

and you wanted to have
them as separate servers,
separate containers, you could do that.

- It sounds like a
great way to really take
some of these older applications

and move them into a modern
application architecture.
- With standard CICD process.
- I mean, it sounds great,
and I am excited to see this in the field

and help our customers
really take advantage

of the ability to containerize
their applications,

to simplify their
migration into the cloud.
- I also should mention that App2Container

is a free tool from Amazon,
